Image, table 5 Image, table 5 64 100 Solvent-free oxidative esterification of furfural to 2-methyl furoate using novel copper-exchanged tungstophosphoric acid supported on montmorillonite K-10 catalyst Deepak S. Desai Ganapati D. Yadav ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai 400019, India Department of Chemical Engineering Institute of Chemical Technology Nathalal Parekh Marg Matunga Mumbai 400019 India Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Nathalal Parekh Marg, Matunga, Mumbai 400019, India ⁎ Corresponding author. The valorization of bio-based chemicals using green processes plays a vital role in the up-gradation of biofuels that are useful to reduce the demand for fossil feedstock. Furfural is a promising renewable biomass-based platform chemical, which can be catalyically transformed into many value-added chemicals. Oxidative esterification of furfural produces 2-methyl furoate, which is used as flavour and fragrance in fine chemical industries. There lies a challenge to find a cheaper and efficient catalyst for one-pot oxidative esterification of furfural. Supported heteropolyacids (HPAs) are useful for many biomass transformation reactions owing to their strong Bronsted acidity as well as high surface area, which both help promote catalytic surface reaction. In the present work, we have synthesized Cu exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) with different supports, viz. SiO2, ZrO2, and montmorillonite K-10 clay (K10) which were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. Oxidative esterification of furfural with methyl alcohol was investigated using the aforesaid catalysts and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant. 20% w/w Cu substituted TPA (abbreviated as Cu-TK10) catalyst is green, stable, active, selective, reusable, and cheaper. It was observed that the higher acidic strength and good surface area are responsible for oxidative esterification of furfural and methyl alcohol with higher selectivity. In this work, 91% conversion with 100% selectivity was achieved in 5 h at 120 °C using 1:3 molar ratio of furfural and TBHP with a catalyst loading of 0.01 g/cm3. The synthesized catalysts were analyzed by various characterization techniques such as SEM, XRD, FT-IR, BET surface area analyser, and NH3-TPD, before and after use. This is an interesting example of valorization of furfural. The fossil resources are not going to satisfy the societal needs of materials and energy for a longer time due to their depletion and above all their detrimental effect on environment. Therefore, biomass, both virgin and waste, can become a valuable source for provision of chemicals, materials and energy [1,2]. Biomass is an essential resource in the production of more sustainable energy, chemicals and fuels than various other renewable resources [3]. Worldwide ~10-14% energy need is contributed by biomass, while ∼ 90% energy required by rural and remote areas of developing countries is provided by biomass [4–6]. Biobased chemicals are derived by physical, chemical or biological treatment [7–9]. The lignocellulosic biomass consists of lignin (15-20%), cellulose (40-50%), and hemicellulose (25-35%) [10–13]. The hemicellulosic biomass has been converted into the C5 or C6 sugar units. The C5 or C6 sugar fractions of biomass produce furanic compounds such as 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) and furfural by catalytic conversion, which are major constituents for the biorefinery industries. They can be used for the synthesis of renewable gasoline, diesel and jet fuels [14–16]. Moreover, renewable agriculture (i. e., food crop residues and wastes) is a furfural production source [17]. Furfural is a renewable, biomass-derived chemical that can be transformed into various value-added products like furfural acetone, furfuryl alcohol, furan tetrahydrofuran, cyclopentone, methyltetrahydrofuran, furoyl, furfurylidene, 2-methylfuran, etc. [18–22]. Furfural (C5H4O2) is a 5-membered oxygen-containing heterocyclic compound having two functional groups (i.e. aromatic ring and carbonyl group). Furfural is involved in many named reactions and rearrangements, viz. aldol condensation, Knoevenagel condensation, Cannizzaro reaction, Friedel-Craft acylation, alkylation acetalization, reductive amination, decarboxylation, reduction of alcohol, hydrogenation, oxidation, and Grignard reaction [17,23]. Among all these reactions, one-pot oxidative esterification of furfural with aliphatic alcohol gives a valuable furanic upgraded product 2-alkyl furoate. The furfural oxidative esterification was performed with methyl alcohol using various oxidizing agents like tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), air, and molecular oxygen [24]. 2-Methyl furoate is used as an extracting agent in various industries as well as in flavour, fragrance and fine chemical companies [25]. Previously, oxidative methyl-esterification of furfural using methanol has been studied by various heterogeneous catalysts. Taarning at al. [26] have reported 100% furfural conversion and 100% selectivity under mild reaction conditions at 22°C in 10-12 h with NaOCH3 using Au/TiO2 catalyst. Au metal with different supports like Fe2O3, CeO2, TiO2, and C have been tested by Casanova et al. [27]. They obtained 100% conversion of furfural with 100% 2-methyl furoate selectivity using 10 bar O2 pressure at 130°C in 5 h using Au/ CeO2 catalyst. Kegnaes et al. [28] used Au/TiO2 catalyst with KCH3O as a base for oxidative coupling of various aldehydes and alcohols, leading to 100% conversion and 100%selectivity at 25°C in 24 h. Tong et al. [29] studied Au metal with various supports, namely, FxOy - hydroxyapatite (FH), Fe3O4, CeO2 and K2CO3 as a base at 140°C for 4 h. Among these catalysts, Au/FH showed the highest efficacy for oxidative esterification. Gold supported on sulfonated zirconia (Au/ZrO2) catalyst gave the best result due to the presence of Au cluster, which dissociates molecular oxygen and produces atomic oxygen with basic properties that might have helped in the activation of CH3OH [30]. Co3O4-N@C catalysts were prepared by Rajenahally et al. [31] using pyrolysis of nitrogen-ligated cobalt (II) acetate on a commercial carbon support, and they obtained 100% conversion and 77% yield at 70°C in 24 h with K2CO3 base. Deng et al. [32] studied the use of Co, Pd, and Mn metals with 1,10 phenanthroline and 2,2-dipyridine ligands as catalysts for the oxidative esterification of furfural. They got an excellent result with 100% conversion with 77% yield using Co(1,10-phen)/C catalyst with K2CO3 base at 60°C in 12 h. Kiran et al. [33] used N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) catalyst with 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) base for the synthesis of 2-methyl furoate from furfural and obtained 24% conversion and 63% yield at 25°C. Silva and Rodrigues [34] used metal silicotungstate salts (i.e., Cu2SiW12O40) as catalysts in furfural oxidation reactions with hydrogen peroxide and obtained 90% yield at 50°C in 1 h. More recently, Gupta et al. [35] prepared CuO/m-Al2O3 catalyst with various copper content and studied its activity using TBHP for the oxidative esterification of HMF and furfural. They got 80% yield at 100°C in 20 h. Among all the solid acid catalysts, heteropoly acids (HPAs) are outstanding catalysts due to their unique structure, remarkable physicochemical properties as well as super Bronsted acidity, high proton mobility, quick multi-electron mobility, and high solubility in different solvents [36,37]. Strong Bronsted acidity of the HPAs is useful for a wide variety of catalytic transformations of biomass. It gives a remarkably higher conversion and selectivity of the desired product, which is attractive for future industrial biomass valorization [38]. HPAs can be made as a heterogeneous acid catalyst using suitable supports and by exchanging the proton with various metal ions [39]. Supported HPAs are very efficient for a variety of acid-catalyzed and oxidation reactions [39–42]. Previously Silva et al. [43] studied the oxidation of benzaldehyde by hydrogen peroxide over K6SiW11CoO39 catalyst. They achieved 91% benzaldehyde conversion with 100% benzoic acid selectivity at 60°C in 4 h. Na4PMo11VO40 catalyst was used by Vilanculo and Silva [44] for the one-pot oxidative esterification of benzaldehyde with ethyl alcohol in the presence of hydrogen peroxide. They focused on theeffect of the vanadium loading on the conversion as well as the selectivity of the reactions and achieved 90% yield at 50°C in 5 h. Among all HPAs, the supported tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) has shown an excellent catalytic activity because of the Keggin-type structure and super acidic properties [40]. Supported TPA possesses a higher surface area that helps overcome the solubility in polar solvents and increases the catalyst efficiency. Moreover, the metal exchanged TPA increases the Bronsted acidic sites as well as Lewis acidic sites. In the previous literature, researchers exchanged protons of TPA by different metal ions partially or entirely, such as Cs [45], Pd [46], Al [47], and Sn [48], with various supports, namely, silica [49], graphene [50], alumina [51], active carbon [52], titania [46], and montmorillonite K-10 clay [45]. Among all these, montmorillonite K-10 clay (K10) support is cheap and possesses a higher surface area with an acidic nature, which enhances the catalytic activity by the dispersion of Keggin ions. Our group reported various metal ion-exchanged HPAs with K10 support for the synthesis of different industrially important chemicals [53]. Herein, we introduced novel 20% w/w Cu metal ion-exchanged TPA (Cu-TK10), which was highly active and selective catalyst for the synthesis of 2-methyl furoate from furfural under solventless reaction conditions, which leads to green economic process. Cu-TK10 catalyst is stable, active, selective, reusable, and cheaper than previously reported catalysts. TBHP is a commercially available and cheaper peroxide which contains highly active oxygen for the oxidation reaction. Moreover, it is environmentally friendly because their reduced product is tert-butanol that is easy to remove from the reaction mixture [54]. For this reaction, TBHP (70%) is used as an oxidizing agent in a suitable ratio, and MeOH not only acts as a reactant but also as solvent. The various optimized reaction parameters achieve the optimal catalytic activity. Various catalysts used in this study were characterized using different techniques, viz. SEM, XRD, FT-IR, NH3-TPD, and BET surface area. The reaction mechanism was predicted. The reaction kinetics was also examined by using a kinetic study. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Montmorillonite K-10 clay (Sigma Aldrich, USA), dodeca-tungustophosphoric acid hydrated, tert-butyl hydroperoxide (S. D. Fine Chemicals, Mumbai, India), and CuCl2.3H2O (Loba Chemie), methanol, and furfural (Fisher Scientific, India) were used as received without any further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation All catalysts were synthesized using the incipient wetness impregnation. Dodeca- tungustophosphoric acid (TPA) was loaded on K10 to achieve 20% w/w. The proton (H+) of TPA exchanged by Cu atom, for instance, 20% w/w Cu1H1PW12O40/K-10 (Cux-TPA/K-10, x=1.5-0.5) (Cu-TK10) was prepared by two impregnation steps. At first, Cu metal ion was loaded on the K10 for which 8 g K10 support was dried in the oven at 120°C (3 h). Then, the appropriate amount of CuCl2.xH2O (Cu precursor) was taken to make an aqueous solution with 10 mL methyl alcohol. This aqueous solution was dropwise added with constant stirring on dried K10 support. Then material was then kept for drying at 120°C for 2 h. In the second step, TPA was impregnated. The aqueous methanol solution of 2 g TPA was added dropwise in above dried solid (of Cu-K10) material with constant stirring. The resulted material was dried at 120°C for 12 h and further calcined at 300°C for 3 h. Other catalysts were synthesized by a similar incipient wetness impregnation procedure. 2.3 Experimental The reactions were carried out in a 100 cm3 stainless steel batch autoclave (Amar Equipments, Mumbai, India) with an overhead impeller (four bladed-pitched turbine impeller). The PID controller maintained the temperature. A standard experiment consisted of 0.0247 mole (2.37 g) furfural, 0.494 mole (15.83 g) MeOH, 0.0741 mole (6.68 g) TBHP, 0.1 mL n-decane used as internal standard. The optimized reaction was studied in 1200 rpm at 120°C for 5 h. 2.4 Method of analysis GC (Thermo Scientific Trace 1100 model) was used for the continuous analysis of reaction mixture. A stainless steel TG-5 capillary column (0.25 cm length, 30 m internal diameter) with a FID detector and autosampler 7683B series with a 10 μ l syringe was used. The analysis was done using internal standard and GCMS technique (Thermo Scientific Trace 1300 with TG5MS capillary column) was used for the product confirmation. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization techniques All catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method. K10, TK10, Cr0.66-TK10, Cu-TK10, and reused Cu-TK10 calcined catalysts were characterized by using various orthogonal analytical techniques and the methodology is explained in detail in the electronic supplementary information (ESI). 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 XRD Fig. 1 depicts the XRD diffractogram for K10, TK10, Cr0.66-TK10, Cu-TK10 and reused Cu-TK10 catalysts. Peaks at 20° and 35° showed with planes 110 and 105 due to K10 [55]. Moreover, K10 has made of various phases that include other impurities and materials which were observed in XRD pattern, namely, quartz at 21.1°, 26.5°, 50.1°, 59.8°; feldspar at 27.9°, and phengite at 36.6°, 42.5°, 45.6° [56–59]. The overall XRD diffractogram shows a similar pattern, which indicates that the impregnation of TPA and metal exchanged TPA on K10 clay was successful. It also confirms uniform distribution of Keggin anion due to the surface interaction of K10 [55,60]. The XRD patterns of fresh and reused Cu exchanged TPA (Cu-TK10) catalysts were almost similar. This validated the reusability of the catalyst. 3.2.2 FTIR The FTIR spectra of K10, TK10, Cr0.66-TK10, Cu-TK10, and reused Cu-TK10 catalysts are represented in Fig. 2. The TPA shows the Keggin tetrahedral structure, which consists of phosphorous, a central atom that is coordinated by four oxygen and surrounded by twelve octahedral units. The band peaks were observed at 520, 790, 891, 987 cm−1 due to the bending vibration, edge shared corner, a terminal of O-P-O, W-O-W, W-O-W, and W=O, respectively. A peak at 1080 cm-1 of P-O of the central tetrahedral PO4 unit of the Keggin tetrahedral structure of TPA, which consists of phosphorous, is a central atom that is coordinated by four oxygen and surrounded by twelve octahedral units [40,61,62]. The broad peak at 1620 cm−1 showed the -H-O-H bending frequency of moisture contents of the catalyst. The peaks between 3100 and 3600 cm−1 were observed because of absorbed water molecules in K10 [59]. As per the previous report [63], FTIR spectra of K10 support was similar to that of TPA loaded K10. It was observed in the case of fresh Cu-TK10 as well as reused Cu-TK10 TPA loaded Keggin anion was stable under reaction conditions. 3.2.3 NH3-TPD The acidic strength distribution of the catalysts was determined using the NH3-TPD analytical technique from 100 to 650°C (Fig. 3). The acidic strength is split up into three regions according to temperature, namely, 1500-250°C (weak), 250-450°C (moderate), and above 450°C (high) [64]. The support K10 is made by acidic treatment of montmorillonite clay and hence it is acidic in nature. A peak was observed between 100 and 300°C, which is in the weak acidity region [65]. After the loading of TPA and metal exchanged TPA on K10 support, peaks were found in the weak and moderate to strong acidity region according to temperature. TK10 and metal exchanged TK10 catalysts show higher acidity than the K10 support because the extra acidity comes up with TPA and its salt. The total acidity was in the following order: Cu-TK10> reused Cu-TK10> Cr0.66-TK10 > TK10 > K10 (Table 1 ). Cu exchanged TK10 resulted in the moderate to strong higher acidity region than Cr exchanged TK10 and TK10. The overall acidity of all the catalysts is shown in Table 1. 3.2.4 SEM SEM was used to study the surface morphology of Cu-TK10 catalyst (Fig. 4). Agglomeration was found after the loading TPA on K10, and the morphology of Cu-TK10 showed a smooth surface, which is similar to that mentioned in previous reports [40,55,60]. 3.3 BET analysis K10, TK10, Cr0.66-TK10, Cu-TK10, and reused Cu-TK10 catalysts were analyzed using the nitrogen adsorption and desorption techniques by BJH and multiple BET methods to quantify the surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter. The catalysts showed well defined stages in nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms (Fig. 5). K10 support showed a higher surface area, but it reduced after the TPA loading because TPA could have blocked smaller pores of K10 that resisted N2 adsorption. The metal exchanged TK10 showed a higher surface area than the TK10 due to the dense porous network [60]. The fresh and reused Cu-TK10 showed nearly similar surface area, and the activity change was insignificant (Table 2 ). 3.4 Catalytic reaction Scheme 1 shows the reaction pathways for the synthesis of 2-methyl furoate from furfural with methanol by Cu-TK10 catalyst using tert-butyl hydrogen peroxide (TBHP) as an oxidizing agent. The detailed surface mechanism is given in Scheme 2 . 3.5 Effect of different oxidants The oxidative esterification of furfural was studied using oxidizing agents such as TBHP and H2O2 at 120 °C. TBHP and H2O2 resulted in the oxidised desired product with a molar ratio of 1: 3 furfural to oxidant. In Fig. 6 , TBHP shows a higher yield because the radical species of TBHP is more stable than H2O2. Therefore, TBHP was suitable for the same reaction. A reaction was also performed without any oxidant under a similar reaction condition. It was observed that reaction proceeded till 2-furaldehyde-dimethyl-acetal (acetal) intermediate for all catalysts, but it did not proceed to the next oxidation step to 2-methyl furoate. All the catalysts showed different activity due their different acidic strength. Cu-TK10 gave higher activity due to higher acidic strength. 3.6 Screening of various catalysts The bulk TPA catalyst showed high activity in the oxidative esterification of furfural with methanol due to higher Bronsted acidic strength and achieved 76% furfural conversion with 98% selectivity to 2-methyl furoate. However, it was observed that TPA is soluble in polar solvents and can easily leach into reaction media. In the reaction system, TPA behaves as a homogeneous catalyst since water is formed as a co-product during the reaction. Bhadra and Yadav [66] also reported similar observations in the synthesis of triarylmethane synthesis from anisole with benzaldehyde. Due to this reason, TPA was not selected for further studies. The unsupported Cu exchanged TPA resulted 38% conversion of furfural and 84% selectivity of the desired product, which is higher than K10 support alone. However, the activity Cu exchanged TPA increased when it was loaded on suitable supports, which enhances acidity as well as surface area. Therefore, the current work focused on metal exchanged TPA with various supports, viz., K10, TK10, Cr0.66-TK10, Cu-TK10, Cu-TZrO2, Cu-TSiO2 under similar reaction conditions (Fig.7 ). Montmorillonite K10 clay was made by acid treatment, which is more acidic than other screened supports. Therefore, K10 supported catalysts were more efficient than the SiO2 and ZrO2. Among all catalysts, metal exchanged TK10 catalysts showed higher catalytic activity due to higher Bronsted acidity. The metal exchanged TPA leads to the higher mobility of residual proton of TPA, which increases the Bronsted acidity. However, the Keggin structure is not damaged by the metal exchanged process, and it allows to generate more acidic sites. Cr exchanged TK10 catalyst showed higher activity than both TK10 and K10 for the Friedel-Craft acylation of furan in our previous work [63]. However, it is interesting that Cu exchanged modified TK10 catalyst is more efficient than Cr exchanged TK10 catalyst for oxidative esterification reaction of furfural. Cu-TK10 catalyst obtained 91% conversion with 100% selectivity, which was higher than other catalysts. The catalytic activity order is as follows: Cu − TK 10 ( best ) > C r 0 . 66 − TK 10 > TK 10 > Cu − TZr O 2 > Cu − TSi O 2 > K 10 . The strong Bronsted acidity of Cu-TK10 catalyst plays a vital role in its catalytic activity. Moreover, Cu-TK10 has a higher surface area that provides more accessibility of acidic sites for the surface reaction inside the pores. The results of XRD, FTIR, TGA, and NH3-TPD characterizations support the higher catalytic activity of the catalyst. 3.7 Effect of speed of agitation The effect of speed of agitation study helps to find out the optimum speed at which the external mass transfer resistance can be omitted. It was performed in the range of 800-1400 rpm (Fig. 8 ). The overall conversion of furfural increased till 1200 rpm, above which there was insignificant change in the conversion. Thus, it was confirmed that the mass transfer resistance was overcome at and beyond 1200 rpm which was considered as the optimum speed of agitation. 3.8 Effect of catalyst loading Catalyst loading in the range of 0.050 g/cm3 to 0.125 g/cm3 was studied (Fig. 9 ). The catalyst activity increases with an increase in catalyst amount because of the higher availability of active sites for the reaction. When a plot of initial rate of reaction and catalyst loading was made, it was observed that the reaction rate was directly proportional to the amount of catalyst loading (Fig. 10 ). Thus, 0.01 g/cm3 was considered as optimum catalyst loading for further parameter studies. Moreover, there was no noticeable difference observed in the selectivity of desired product at all catalyst loadings. 3.9 Effect of mole ratio of furfural to methanol In this reaction, MeOH acts as a solvent as well as a reactant, and it makes the process green by avoiding hazardous or unsafe solvents. The effect of mole ratio of furfural: MeOH was studied from 1:5 to 1:30 under the same reaction conditions keeping the catalyst loading (g/cm3) the same (Fig. 11 ). It was found that as the concentration of MeOH was increased, the rate of reaction increased. But, when the molar ratio was changed from 1:20 to 1:30, there was no significant change in the conversion of furfural. Hence, the mole ratio of 1:20 (furfural and MeOH) was considered as optimum for further studies. 3.10 Effect of mole ratio of furfural to TBHP The effect of mole ratio of furfural to TBHP was studied over the range of 1:1 to 1:4 (Fig. 12 ). The rate of formation of 2-methyl furoate increased with an increase in TBHP concentration due to the generation of O2 for oxidation. The concentration of TBHP helps to attain faster oxidation of furfural. A mole ratio of 1:3 gave the optimal conversion of 91%. Further increase in TBHP concentration did not result in significant change in furfural conversion. Therefore, all further experiments were carried out in 1:3 mole ratio. 3.11 Effect of temperature The effect of temperature on the conversion of furfural was studied from 100 to 130°C (Fig. 13 ). The conversion of furfural surged with increasing reaction temperature that validated the reaction was an intrinsically kinetically controlled.. At 120°C, there was 91% conversion, and beyond 120°C, only a marginal difference was observed in the furfural conversion. However, the selectivity of the desired product varied with temperature. From 100 to 120 °C, the selectivity of the desired product was similar, i.e., 100%. However, the selectivity decreased slightly by 2% (98%) at 130 °C (Table 3 )) which was within experimental error. On the basis of both conversion and selectivity of desired product, t 120 °C was selected as the optimum reaction temperature. The obtained data were utilized to calculate the initial rate of reaction, and the Arrhenius plot was made tofind the activation energy. 3.12 Reaction mechanism For oxidative esterification reaction, the catalyst requires both sites, acidic as well as metallic sites. The oxidation reaction mechanism using TBHP as oxidant was previously reported in our lab [67] (Scheme 2). Cu-TK10 catalyst has two sites: one acts as the acidic site (S), and another is an oxidizing site (metal site or M). Initially, furfural gets converted to 2-furaldehyde-dimethyl-acetal (acetal) intermediate in the presence of MeOH on acidic sites, and further this acetal gets oxidized using TBHP as an oxidant with a 1:3 (furfural: TBHP) mole ratio in the presence of metallic sites and results into the desired product, i.e., 2-methyl furoate. 3.13 Development of a mathematical model A mathematical model for the oxidative esterification reaction was developed on the basis of a possible reaction mechanism (Scheme 2). As per the mechanism, the desired product was achieved through hemiacetal and acetal formation. Hence, we have summarized the overall reaction scheme through a single intermediate formation (i.e., acetal), where furfural (A), methanol (B), acetal (C), TBHP (D), and 2-methyl furoate (E). The dual site of the catalyst follows the Langmuir−Hinshelwood-Hougen−Watson (LHHW) mechanism for the current reaction. The furfural and methanol adsorbed on the catalytic acidic site S. (1) A + S → K A A S (2) B + S → K B B S The adsorbed species AS and BS on surface reaction results in the intermediate CS as (3) A S + B S ↔ k 1 k 1 ′ C S + S Further the oxidizing agent adsorbed on metallic site M. The Arrhenius plots are provided in ESI (Figure S1 and S2). The activation energy for forward and backword reactions of step 1 was found to be 15.26 kcal mol−1 and 17.96 kcal mol−1 , respectively and the activation energy for step 2 was found to be 14.60 kcal mol−1. Hence the reaction is kinetically controlled. 3.14 Reusability study For studying the reusability, the catalyst was isolated after each reaction using the filtration technique and then washed with the reaction solvent for 3 h at reflux conditions to desorb any adsorbed impurities from the surface and pores of the catalyst, dried at 120 °C for 12 h, and further calcined at 300°C. There were losses of the catalyst during the handling process, which were made up by adding fresh catalyst. This study was carried out for three consecutive runs after fresh use. Nearly the same catalytic efficiency was observed in the reused catalyst and fresh catalyst (Fig. 14 ). Therefore, the catalyst was relatively reusable and characterized by various analytical techniques along with fresh catalyst. 3.15 Oxidative esterification of furfural with ethanol, n-butanol, and isopropanol The oxidative esterification of furfural with different alcohols, namely, ethanol (Table 5 , Entry 1), n-butanol (Table 5, Entry 2), and isopropanol (Table 5, Entry 3) was carried out under similar reaction conditions. It was observed that the catalyst showed different activities with different alcohols. Irrespective of the type of alcohol used in this study, >99% selectivity was achieved in all the reactions. However, the conversion of the substrate varies with the type of alcohol. The branched alcohols resulted in less conversion than linear alcohols due to a higher steric hindrance [68]. Conclusion Oxidative esterification of furfural produces 2-methyl furoate, which is used as flavour and fragrance in fine chemical industries. There lies a challenge to find a cheaper and efficient catalyst for the one-pot oxidative esterification of furfural. It was achieved in this work by copper modified HPA. The support K10 proved to be an efficient for HPAs compared to other supports, viz., SiO2, ZrO2. The Cu-TK10 catalyst was found to be the best for the selective oxidative esterification of furfural using TBHP as an oxidizing agent without use of any external solvent. This catalyst was not ony efficient with respect to activity and selectivity but also economically viable. The reaction resulted in 91% conversion, and 100% selectivity of 2-methyl furoate at 120°C, with 1:3 furfural to TBHP mole ratio at 0.01 g/cm3 catalyst loading. In addition, the catalyst was found to be fairly reusable and it could be used in oxidative esterification of other alcoholsVarious analytical characterization techniques supported the stability and reusability of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The valorization of bio-based chemicals using green processes plays a vital role in the up-gradation of biofuels that are useful to reduce the demand for fossil feedstock. Furfural is a promising renewable biomass-based platform chemical, which can be catalyically transformed into many value-added chemicals. Oxidative esterification of furfural produces 2-methyl furoate, which is used as flavour and fragrance in fine chemical industries. There lies a challenge to find a cheaper and efficient catalyst for one-pot oxidative esterification of furfural. Supported heteropolyacids (HPAs) are useful for many biomass transformation reactions owing to their strong Bronsted acidity as well as high surface area, which both help promote catalytic surface reaction. In the present work, we have synthesized Cu exchanged tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) with different supports, viz. SiO2, ZrO2, and montmorillonite K-10 clay (K10) which were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. Oxidative esterification of furfural with methyl alcohol was investigated using the aforesaid catalysts and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant. 20% w/w Cu substituted TPA (abbreviated as Cu-TK10) catalyst is green, stable, active, selective, reusable, and cheaper. It was observed that the higher acidic strength and good surface area are responsible for oxidative esterification of furfural and methyl alcohol with higher selectivity. In this work, 91% conversion with 100% selectivity was achieved in 5 h at 120 °C using 1:3 molar ratio of furfural and TBHP with a catalyst loading of 0.01 g/cm3. The synthesized catalysts were analyzed by various characterization techniques such as SEM, XRD, FT-IR, BET surface area analyser, and NH3-TPD, before and after use. This is an interesting example of valorization of furfural.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-free oxidative esterification of furfural to 2-methyl furoate using novel copper-exchanged tungstophosphoric acid supported on montmorillonite K-10 catalyst
